newsitem.title: USA: Genetics Institute files Factor IX.
newsitem.headline: Genetics Institute files Factor IX.

text.p: Genetics Institute Inc said on Wednesday it had filed for marketing approval for its recombinant Factor IX, used to treat hemophilia B, in the U.S., Canada and Europe.

The company said it filed a Biological License Application with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, a New Drug Submission with the Canadian Health Protection Branch and a Marketing Authorization Application with the European Medicines Evaluation Agency. Genetics Institute's chief operating officer Patrick Gage said the filings were the company's first for a proprietary product.
Hemophilia B is caused by a deficiency or defect in Factor IX, one of a number of proteins involved in blood clotting.
Recombinant Factor IX offers the potential to eliminate the risk of blood-borne viral transmission associated with Factor IX therapies made from human plasma, Genetics Institute said.
Current blood-derived Factor IX clotting therapies make up an worldwide market of about $150 million.
